narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: This course covered a lot of ground quickly and usefully. It was nice to have such a comprehensive study of sustainability attempts in the developing world.

Question 7: Ellen is one of the best professor's I've had; not only is she phenomenally well-versed and excited about the material, but she also takes interest in the well-being of her students and provided a very welcoming atmosphere in class. She's awesome.Question 10: I'm interested in sustainable urban development, and this course definitely showed me a lot of the challenges in that field. However, it's very heavy on case studies and the like, and I think it would be awesome to spend more time on proposed solutions and discussion of those solutions.

I thought the material in this course was very interesting but it was not taught in the best way. The lectures seemed more to be straight facts and the same case studies were repeated. I would have enjoyed more applied scenarios and opportunities to engage in the subject matter. There was not a lot of work in this class and the readings were not helpful. There was one paper and it is unclear how excatly we will be graded.
Ellen is a wonderful lecturer and a fascinating person--Temperance was also great as a TA. I think the course material is very important, and will only become more topical in the coming years!
It is a great course

It is a shame that the course will not be given next semester. Is a good course to learn a lot about real problems! Identify posible solutions that many cities are facing and connect this problems with best practice and sucessful projects around the world. I really learnt a lot.
-the course lost structure at times, which is expected with a broad survey course but certainly introduced several interesting topics.

Question 10 - The topic of urban sustainability is vitally important, and even though this instructor is poor and the class is being eliminated WE NEED MORE CLASSES ON THIS TOPIC.Question 5 - Students asked questions all the time, but I don't think any student all semester got their question out in its entirety without the instructor interrupting the student and giving a terse answer. Literally every question was interrupted.

Re: Question 10This material is VERY important for students to be able to learn- there is nothing more important to the future of the environment than the sustainable development of the world's cities.

The wide range of topics covered was great. I also liked how the class emphasized creative solutions to the problems it raised. Ellen was a wonderful lecturer and very open to student direction in the class.
It is very practical and down to the ground. It's a great course taught by experienced professor and the guest lecturers are great!
The professor and the lectures; I heard the trips were good, but I could never make it.
It was a course on cities and sustainability, which in my opinion is one of the most important topics in sustainability and urban design.
The breadth of topics and issues covered, supported with ample statistics, and case studies.
The subject matter was very interesting. Each class was a different topic that could have had its own semester long course.
The lectures.

It is the only course in FES and in Yale that gives an overview of the environmental chllanges confronted in the urban sphere. Its absence next year will be a grave loss to the school, and will leave a huge gap in solutions this school can provide for the most exacting problems of our times. Most environmental policy making today and in the future pertains to cities, that is where most of humanity already lives, where energy is most widely consumed, and where a change in living patterns in crucial for the sustainability of this planet. Not offering such a course is a disadvantage i'm not sure this school has any idea currently on how to overcome.
Guest speaker are great.
I get to know a lot about urban development in this course.
-the variety of readings.
I enjoyed the guest speakers we had.
The subject matter -- Yale has too few graduate urban studies classes.
Exposure to range of environmental issues in cities.

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: There could be slightly fewer statistics in each lecture so they wouldn't have to be as rushed.
More time spent discussing proposed solutions and acting like urban planner, which is what I was anticipating at the outset.
The course was very survey like, and while I learned more about conditions in various parts of the world, there were few truly indepth case examples other than Singapore.
The structure of the lectures and the different options of assignments. The style was a bit repetative after awhile.
Nothing.

I felt the class attempted to cover too many areas related to city development, and as a result the material was spread rather thinly over too many areas to really be of much benefit to a graduate student.
The content is too general. More case study will give a deeper understanding of the topics.
-some of the lectures tended to be tangential, however that can be expected at times.

I think this course maybe needs more focus. Our readings were so varies because "development in cities" is such an enormous subject to tackle. I think this course could be divided into several courses.
The material was presented too macro and was rather repetitive -- we didn't dive very far into specific topics or do any case studies.
Lectures were interesting, but sort of unstructured. With fewer tangents and only relevant examples, time could have been used more efficiently and we could have gone deeper into each topic.

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: The instructor and TA were both great---very available to give individual help.
They are very responsive and very helpful.
Ellen was extremely available and really emphasized office hours for students who wanted to talk to her about anything course related or city-related.
Great! I contacted both and both replied quickly and helpfully.
Incredible, both instructor and ta were rapud in their response, extremely helpful and insightful.
They are both very helpful.
it is very helpfull
very available.

The TA (Temperance) was excellent. She was very helpful/clear.The instructor was not as responsive but still helpful. The instructor attended class after trauma to the back and was on pain medication - I think it would have been best for her to not teach that day, since it was clear she was unwell.
Both very available and helpful.

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: I am an urban studies concentrator in Yale College. This class gave the perfect international component to a study of urban issues.
It gave me a broader view on the global perspective.
The subject matter aligns with my interests and overall career goals in urban planning.
It is the key to my masters degree, as it should be to anyone who wishes to work in and on cities.
It's too general to have a deep understanding of the topics.
-course allowed for a broad survey.

This course is perfect for my course of study: I am interested in health issues, development issues, and environmental issues. This course covered all the areas I am interested in. But, again, the topic of this course was too big for one semester. It should be divided into multiple courses.
This topic of this course is exactly what I'm interested in (although my focus is more in the developed world). I was disappointed that the instructor was so poor.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I took this course to get an international look at urban issues, and to see creative solutions to some of these problems.
I'm very interested in the environmental issues and sustainable development.
I'm an undergraduate interested in sustainable city development abroad, so this course fit perfectly with my interests.

I was interested in how cities around the world were integrating sustainable design into their planning. However, we covered the same case examples every time, and some times I felt like lecture really overlapped.
Because I thought it would give me more insight into subject areas I was already interested in.
I am very interested in Urban Studies and Sustainability.
Because I am interested in urban issues and the instructor is leaving next year.
interest
-to learn about sustainability practices outside of the US.
It fits in well with my program of study.
It's exactly what I'm interested in.
ONLY course on the urban environment offered at Yale University (I'm an undergrad. This course is very valuable!)

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: Yes, this course lived up to my expectations.
yes
No
Not excatly.
Yes.
Yes, it was excellent.
No.
I felt that there should have been more structure in the lectures or a better expession of learning objectives.
Yes
Yes, the course was great.
Just under my expectations in terms of amount of knowledge and practical skills obtained. some of the readings were a bit outdated for sustainability studies.
Somewhat. We covered several topics. And I think it was too high a goal to cover everything in depth. This course was a great overview of development topics within a city.
No -- we didn't go into any depth and the material was presented in rapid-fire bullet points.

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: I absolutely got out of this course what I expected.
Yes, the course covered a wide range of relevant topics with updated information.
Yes. I put a lot of effort and work into the final paper andthat is where I got a lot out of the class. Again, haivng more assignments would have generated more insight for the students.
Yes.
Yes, completely.
No.
Yes
see answer above.
Yes, I was able to supplement my interests with additional research on the side. It was nice to get an overview to see the issues that are actually out there now.
No.PLEASE ADD MORE URBAN CLASSES.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Group work was great--it was a small project and it allowed participants to divide the work fairly evenly.
I enjoyed the brainstorming within the group.

The interactions with the other group members allow effective exchange of perspectives from members of different nationalities, which is helpful to gaining new insights and ideas on how to tackle urban problems.
It was fun to do the group presentation at the end and I wish I had more time and opportunity to do more with the group. Maybe a group paper with the presentation would have been helpful.
It was great to discuss alternative perspectives on our topic.
Advantages: I worked in a group that shared the same interests as I.we were able to incorporate this into the project we worked on
Combining different perspectives on a single issue to produce new insights.
The time given to the work group is too limited.
we get to share our difference background in the topic of this course
It was great. We were all from different areas (Economists, health, Forestry school) it was interesting to work in a multi-disciplinary group.
the people in the group had different perspectives and it was nice to learn and talk with them.
Got to know more people in the class. We did presentations and I think that was a fun, interesting project for this course.

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Keep an open mind going in about what the role of different bodies are within cities: the government, the private sector, civil society---and see the creative ways in which each of them can help (or hurt) the urban environment.
Attend the lectures! Ellen has lots of fascinating stories and tidbits, and get to know her!
The more you put into this course, the more you will get out of it.
Students will not be able to take this course any more, which is a shame.
If you majored in environmental studies in college, there's no need to take this class.
make sure to do all the readings and follow along in lecture.

The topic is vast, so it's an overview course really. The professor enjoys reminiscing about past work all over the world. The stories are interesting but can get repetitive. Take advantage of the paper and research what you're interested in!
